Meet the faculty of City Tech and Weill Cornell Medicine

  • CUNY Faculty
  • Weill Cornell Medicine Faculty

Evgenia Giannopoulou

Principal Investigator

Dr. Evgenia Giannopoulou, project director and co-principal investigator of the BD2BMI research program, is an assistant professor of Bioinformatics in the Biological Sciences Department at CUNY City College of Technology. She teaches bioinformatics (BIO3352) and computational genomics (BIO3354) in the biomedical informatics baccalaureate (BIB) program.

Read more…

Also, Professor Giannopoulou is an adjunct assistant scientist at the David Z. Rosensweigh Genomics Research Center at the Hospital for Special Surgery. There, she is involved in high-throughput data analysis and biologically-driven projects related to rheumatoid arthritis (RA), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and other autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.

Professor Giannopoulou holds a BS in Computer Science from Athens University of Economics and Business PhD in Computer Science/Bioinformatics from University of Peloponnese and a Postdoctoral in Computational Biology from Cornell University.

Jeremy Seto

Faculty

Dr. Jeremy Seto, is an assistant professor in the Biological Sciences Department at CUNY City College of Technology and an adjunct instructor at NYU Tandon School of Engineering. At NYU, he teaches transcriptomics analysis and functional genomics and predictions- bringing together biology and informatics to see the rationale behind analysis.

Read more…

Professor Seto’s research focuses on the innate immune responses to viral infection and the involvement of immune activation in neuropsychiatric disease. His goal is to identify the effects of traditional immune cytokines in inflammation and stress models in neuropsychiatric disorders stemming from chronic inflammation or stress models by utilizing systems based approaches.

Professor Seto holds a BA in Biological Sciences and Psychology from Rutgers College - Rutgers University and PhD in Neuroscience from Weill Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University.

Mai Zahran

Faculty

Dr. Mai Zahran is a professor of biology at CUNY City College of Technology where she teaches bioinformatics (BIO3350) and molecular modeling in biology (BIO3356).

Read more…

Throughout Professor Zahran’s career, she has been involved in the study of chemical and physical processes in biological macromolecules using computer stimulations. Her research interests include: computational molecular modeling, protein-DNA interaction, molecular recognition, structure prediction and understanding the mechanism of action of restriction and repair enzymes.

Professor Zahran holds a BS in Biology and Bioinformatics from University of Evry-Val-D’Essonne, MS in Computational Molecular Biology and Bioinformatics from University Paris Diderot, PhD in Computational Biology from Ruprecht-Karls-Universität and Postdoctoral in Computational Biology from NYU.

Armando D. Solis

Faculty

Dr. Armando D. Solis is an assistant professor in the Biological Sciences Department at CUNY City College of Technology where he teaches biology (1101) and elements of bioinformatics (3350).

Read more…

Professor Solis’ research work in is in the rapidly expanding field of structure bioinformatics. His multi-pronged research program is directed to answering a number of important questions relating to macromolecular structure, including: how protein sequences fold into their unique three-dimensional structures; what signals are present in amino acid sequences that direct this folding; how these signals can be encodedin simplified sequences (both in de novodesigned proteins and in early prebiotic proteins in proteogenesis); and also how proteins and nucleic acids (DNA and RNA) interact specifically in the molecular level.

Professor Solis holds a BS in Agricultural and Biological Engineering from Cornell University, MS in Chemical Engineering from Yale University, MPhil in Biomedical Sciences from Graduate Center, CUNY and PhD in Biomedical Sciences from Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

Joanne Weinreb Daniels

Faculty

Dr. Joanne Weinreb Daniels is an assistant professor in the Department of Biology and program coordinator for Biomedical Informatics Baccalaureate Program at CUNY City College of Technology.

Read more…

Professor Daniels’ research interests lie around developing tools for ‘big data’ analysis. Her current research with groups in Rutger’s University involves using Wikipedia data to assemble disease networks. Her doctoral work at Columbia University involved using Natural Language Processing to remove inconsistencies from a literature-derived molecular interaction network. Additionally, she has worked as a research scientist for BioSof,a company that develops bioinformatics solutions for the annotation, analysis and curation of genomic data, developing PubSeq, a scientific knowledge search and management tool.

Professor Daniels holds a BS in Computer Science from Brooklyn College, MS in Management and Operations Research from NYU Polytechnic University and PhD in Bioinformatics from Columbia University.

Weigang Qiu

Faculty

Dr. Weigang Qiu is an associate professor in Department of Biological Sciences, Hunter College, CUNY and review editor, Evolutionary and Genomic Microbiology, Frontier Journals.

Read more…

As an evolutionary and computational biologist, Professor Qiu is interested in pathogen genome evolution. His research focuses on the natural genetic diversity of Lyme disease bacteria (Borrelia burgdorferi) and its implications for Lyme disease risks. His study approaches evolved from sequencing single locus, to using multiple loci, and to analyzing whole genomes, with concomitant expansion of study scope from local populations to global diversity (C2). The research capacity has advanced from relying primarily on fieldwork and data analysis to including software development (C3) and computational modeling of genome-evolution mechanisms in Borrelia (C4).

Professor Qiu holds a BS in Biochemistry from Fudan University, MS in Biotechnology from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, PhD in Ecology and Evolution from Stony Brook University and Postdoctoral Fellow in Bioinformatics and Evolution from University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute.

Jyotishman Pathak

Co-Principal Investigator

Dr. Jyotishman Pathak, co-principal investigator for BD2BMI, is a Frances and John L. Loeb Professor and Chief, Division of Health Informatics at Weil Cornell Medicine, Cornell University.

Read more…

Professor’s Pathak’s research interest and expertise lies in developing and applying informatics methods for data mining and phenotype extraction from electronic medical records (EMRs), and their applications in pharmacogenomics, comparative effectiveness research, and population health research, particularly focusing on mental health disorders.

Throughout his career, he has lead and collaborated across multiple investigators in several NIH/DHHS consortiums, including, most recently at Mayo, as the Co-PI of eMERGE (http://gwas.org) and PI of PCORI Learning Health Systems Clinical Data Research Network (http://lhsnet.org), and currently at Weill Cornell, as the Co-PI for the PCORI New York City Clinical Data Research Network(http://nyccdrn.org) and the PI for NIH Big Data to Knowledge (BD2K) R25 Training and Education Program on Computational Biomedicine (http://bdc4cm.org).

Professor Pathak holds BS in Computer Science from National Institute of Technology, PhD in Computer Science from Iowa State University and Postdoctoral in Bioinformatics from Mayo Clinic.

Oliver Elemento

Faculty

Dr. Oliver Elemento, is an associate professor at the Institute for Computational Biomedicine, Weil Cornell Medical College.

Read more…

The focus of his group is on the systems biology of cancer; prostate cancer and hematological malignancy levels. The group uses high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-seq, RNA-seq, bisulfite conversion followed by sequencing –specifically RRBS-, ATAC-seq, exome capture and sequencing, single cell RNAseq using DropSeq) to decipher epigenetic mechanisms and regulatory networks at play in malignant cells and study how they affect gene expression.

Professor Elemento leads the computational activities in the Englander Institute for Precision Medicine, which increasingly involve using cloud analytics and storage. In addition he is the associate director of the Institute for Computational Biomedicine, co-assistant dean for Scientific Computing and co-leader of the Cancer Center Program on Genetics and Epigenetics.

Professor Elemento holds a BS in Mechanical Engineering from University of Paul Sabatier, MS in Mechanical Engineering from INSA Toulouse/ University of Nottingham, MS in Artificial Intelligence from University of Montpellier and PhD in Computational Biology from Princeton University.

Doron Betel

Faculty

Dr. Doron Betel is an assistant professor of Computational Biomedicine, Medicine, Division Hematology/Oncology Department and the co-director of Epigenetic Core at Weill Cornell Medical College.

Read more…

As the computational director of the Epigenomic Core, Professor Betel leads a group of computational biologists in developing computational infrastructure specific to the Core activities. The Core devotes considerable research and development efforts towards new methods development and critical assessments of existing methods. Professor Betel also leads a research group which focuses on the development of novel algorithms and computational resources for genomic research. The research group is currently collaborating with a number of research groups in studies of the impact of microbiome on tumor genesis, genetics of colorectal cancer, development of stem-cell models for neurodegenerative diseases and studies of protein-RNA interactions.

Professor Betel holds a BS in Biology/Chemistry from York University, PhD in Computational Biology from University of Toronto and Postdoctoral/Fellow in Computational Biology from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

Jessica S. Ancker

Faculty

Dr. Ancker is an associate professor at the Department of Healthcare Policy & Research, Weill Cornell Medical College and Weill Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences.

Read more…

Professor Ancker’s research centers on using health information technology to improve decisions and healthcare quality using both qualitative and quantitative methods. She has expertise in both electronic health records (EHRs) and consumer information technologies. Additionally, she is a recognized expert in the field of health numeracy and patient decision-making. She conducts health information technology evaluation research, which has been published in leading journals in informatics as well as in general medical journals such as JAMA.

Professor Ancker holds an AB in History and Science from Harvard College, MPH in Biostatistics from Columbia University, Mailman School of Public Health and a PhD in Biomedical Informatics from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

Stephen Johnson

Faculty

Dr. Stephen Johnson is a professor in the Division of Health Informatics, Healthcare Policy and Research and director of Biomedical Informatics, Clinical and Translational Science Center at Weil Cornell Medical College. He currently serves as Chair of the Health Informatics Accreditation Council within the Commission on Accreditation for Health Informatics and Information management (CAHIIM).

Read more…

Professor Johnson is a nationally recognized leader in graduate education in Health Informatics and Bioinformatics. His research explores the use of information systems to promote communication and collaboration in patient care and biomedical research. Notably, Professor Johnson has established one of the first biomedical informatics masters and doctoral training programs in the country, and developed one of the first comprehensive formal curricula for the discipline.

Professor Johnson holds a BA in Computer Science from McGill University and a PhD in Computer Science from New York University.

Fernando Martin-Sanchez

Faculty

Dr. Fernando Martin-Sanchez is an assistant professor at the Division of Health Informatics, Healthcare Policy and Research at Weil Cornell Medical College. As a biomedical informatics scientist, Professor Martin-Sanchez career has spanned across Spain, U.S. and Australia.

Read more…

Professor Martin-Sanchez’s research interests focus on the role of informatics in precision medicine (genome, phenome and exposome data processing) and participatory health (social media, quantified-self, patient reported outcomes). He has conducted research on the application of informatics methods to biomedical research and clinical problems.

Professor Martin-Sanchez holds a BS in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology from Autonomous University of Madrid, MS in Knowledge Engineering and PhD in Informatics from Polytechnic University of Madrid, Postdoctoral in Biomedical Engineering from Emory University Hospital and Georgia Tech and PhD in Medicine from Universidad de A Coruna.

Fei Wang

Faculty

Dr. Fei Wang is an assistant professor in Health Informatics Division, Department of Healthcare Policy and Research at Weill Cornell Medical College. Prior to his current position, he has worked as an associate professor in Department of Computer Science and Engineering at the University of Connecticut.

Read more…

Professor Wang’s primary research interest is data analytics and its applications in health informatics. He has been working on deriving insights from various kinds of biomedical data, especially patient Electronic Health Records (EHR). One of the major research topic he has been working on is large scale computational phenotyping. Professor Wang’s research on computational phenotyping with patient similarity evaluated from their longitudinal EHRs has been transferred to the first IBM software in healthcare industry called IBM Patient Care and Insights. The corresponding paper has been selected as the “best of SDM” in SIAM Data Mining conference 2011.

Professor Wang holds a BS in Automation from Xidian University, MS in Automation and PhD in Automation from Tsinghua University.
